newsitem.title: USA: USDA aide sees good US soy, cotton sales to China.
newsitem.headline: USDA aide sees good US soy, cotton sales to China.

text.p: U.S. soybean and cotton sales to China should continue at their recent healthy pace, but prospects for U.S. wheat and corn are not so promising, a U.S. Agriculture Department aide said Wednesday.

"I would not expect to see us exporting a lot of corn or wheat to China this year," said Scott Reynolds, USDA's agricultural trade officer in Shanghai. "But that doesn't mean (U.S. bulk commodity sales are) completely out because cotton and soybeans and soybean meal are doing very well."
U.S. cotton exports to China totaled slightly more than 1.5 million bales in the first 11 months of 1996-97, down from about 1.75 million for the same period in 1995-96 but still strong.
The big success story this year has been U.S. soybeans, soymeal and soyoil sales to China.

The U.S. has exported more than 1.5 million tonnes of soybeans, 565,500 tonnes of soymeal and 337,600 tonnes of soyoil so far in 1996-97, compared to 263,500 tonnes of soybeans, no soymeal and 135,500 tonnes of soyoil in same period in 1995-96.

Fueling that demand is Chinese hog and poultry production, which has grown rapidly in recent years in response to rising incomes. To a lesser degree, imported soybean and soymeal is also going into Chinese fish farm production, he said.
Forecasts for China to harvest large wheat and corn crops for a second consecutive year have reduced its need for imports of those commodiites, Reynolds said.
In addition, China still refuses to accept U.S. wheat from the Pacific Northwest because of its concerns with a fungus known as TCK smut sometimes present in that crop, he said.
Last year, China's refusal to accept any wheat shipments that might contain TCK smut led to the cancellation of U.S. wheat sales totaling more than 1 million tonnes.
The U.S. has long maintained that China's objections are not based on sound science and that TCK smut poses no threat to human health or to China's own wheat crop.
Nonetheless, China chose to strictly enforce its zero tolerance standard for TCK smut last year despite a 1992 pledge to do away with all food and plant safety standards not based on sound science.
"I'm not sure," Reynolds said, when asked if the Chinese had, in effect, a continuing ban on all U.S. wheat imports.
"The Chinese buy when they wish to buy and it's not always easy to predict that," he said.
But in years like the current one when the Chinese have a large crop, "their import demand will be less," Reynolds said.
"I think that they will be able to meet their needs in wheat (this year) with very small or (zero) imports from the United States," he said.
